name: DevFest Berlin 2014
description:
IMPORTANT: No RSVP here. Buy a ticket to participate. See below for more information.

DEVFEST BERLIN is BACK!

The biggest community conference in Google land is back: For the 3rd time in a row the three Google Developer Groups of Berlin are joining forces to make three days of developer awesomeness happen.

Friday, Nov 21st - half-day of workshops - Android, Go, Polymer

Saturday, Nov 22nd - Conference talks in three parellel tracks: Android, Web, Cloud

Sunday, Nov 23rd - a full day hackathon with a lot of fun and some nice prices

We have some great speakers lined up already and you can check them out here: http://devfest-berlin.de/#/2014/agenda

IMPORTANT: You can't RSVP via Meetup because we want to make sure the seats are taken by people who really want to attend. That's why we are asking for a small fee that is to be paid upon ticket purchase. We promise you'll get your money worth multiple times with workshops, talks, swag, food, prizes and so on. You can get your ticket here ( https://devfest-berlin.ticketbud.com/devfest-berlin-2014 ) and learn more about the event on this site: http://devfest-berlin.de

Let us know if there are any questions!

Hope to see you there!

Your GDG organizers

name: Android Stammtisch November 2014
description:
Join us for the 'Android Stammtisch', the monthly meetup of Android developers in Berlin.

To decide which talks to hear add your vote and/or talk proposal to our Google moderator.

Update:

Unfortunately, the speakers who submitted talks to our Google Moderator can't make it this time.

But luckily, we have a great community. So Stefan Hoth stepped in to give a short talk about what he learned from working on a new Android device. And depending on how bad of a day he had, Juhani Lehtimäki might give his talk to teach developers why design details matter.

Like the last few times you'll also have a chance to give a lightning talk (5 minutes, no product pitches!). Just find one of the organizers before the event.

You might also want to join the Android Stammtisch November 2014 event on Google+ to make sure you're not missing out on the latest chatter. Also, we'd love it if you could share pictures you take of the event there.

name: Android Stammtisch January 2015
description:
We missed you! Join us for our first Android meetup of the year.

The topics will be:

• Short review of GDG Berlin Android's year 2014

• Talk: OpenPGP API: A Case Study of AIDL Versioning by <a>Dominik Schürmann</a>

• If you want to give a lightning talk (5 minutes, no product pitches!), please find one of the organizers before the event.

• Discussion: What would the community like to see at this year's droidcon Berlin?

• Even More Android Code Puzzles by Danny Preussler

To decide which talks we're going hear next time, please add your vote and/or talk proposal to our Google moderator.

Note: The event will be held in english.

name: Stammtisch February 2015
description:
It is time again for our next Stammtisch. 

This time Volker Leck will give us an introduction to Guava. Afterwards the audience have the possibility to give us lightning talks about Android related topics, like new libraries etc., in about 5-10 minutes.

Now you can vote for the possible topics and offer your own. <a>https://www.google.com/moderator/#15/e=204208&t=[masked]﻿</a>;

name: Android Fundamentals Study Group
description:
Google Developers Study Jams (http://developerstudyjams.com/) is a free series of global, community-run, in-person study groups. The first series of sessions is presented in partnership with Udacity and will follow their Android Fundamentals curriculum: https://www.udacity.com/course/ud853

This is a beginners Android workshop that expects Java knowledge.

We will meet 7 weeks in a row always Thursday evening at 8pm. Once we get through the class there will be one last meeting in which everyone will show off their final project. Please come prepared with a notebook running Android Studio and the Android SDK. We also expect you have worked through the respective session. Session 1 for the first meetup.

We will meet at Thoughtworks Werkstatt: http://www.thoughtworks.com/locations/berlin

We're also looking for coaches. If you want to participate as a coach, please do not register here. Instead contact us directly.﻿

description:
Join us for this month's Android meetup! 

Andreas Luedeke will talk about "Getting the android device zoo under control - or how to provision 150+ different android device models within the cloud. Sharing some insights about adb pitfalls, device automation, remote access and stuff you never did with your phone before"

cketti will attempt to teach you "How to avoid the many pitfalls of the Share Intent".

As always there will be plenty of time to talk to fellow Android developers while enjoying a drink or two.

name: Android Recreational Tinkering
description:
This meetup is for hands-on Android tinkering: Developing apps, cooking ROMs, configuring advanced network setups etc.

Tinker alone or in collaboration with others. We'd like to invite beginners and experienced Android users and developers. While the monthly Stammtisch meetup is about talking Android, this meetup is about practical experience with Android.

name: Stammtisch May 2015
description:
Join us for this month's meetup. It's just one day before Google I/O and our very own I/O Extended. So we can have some last-minute speculations on what shiny new things Google will introduce this year.

The first speaker is Volker Leck who will test-run his Droidcon talk Level up your build.

Tricks and techniques of how to extend and customise your Gradle build employing the wide and growing range of Gradle plugins.

The second slot is filled by a guest speaker who will travel all the way from Dresden to join us. Dirk Mahler will talk about Software Analysis using jQAssistant

What happens if you take some software artifacts, scan them and store their structural information into a graph database? You can gather your own metrics, do impact analysis on various levels and even validate your design and architecture constraints. jQAssistant is the open source tool behind this idea and will be presented during the talk.

See you there. And don't forget to join us for I/O Extended, too. http://www.meetup.com/gdgberlin/events/221787414/
https://plus.google.com/events/clc36ru6vnpcn7tnbq97o66pe8k

name: I/O Extended
description:
It's happening! See here for the details: http://www.meetup.com/gdgberlin/events/221787414/

The number of seats is limited. Show up on time if you don't want to stand :)

name: Pre-droidcon Drinks @ c-base
description:
GDG Berlin Android is happy to invite all droidcon Berlin attendees and Android enthusiasts for a get-together on c-base, the crashed space station buried under the city of Berlin.

Meet the local community, chat about barcamp talks and make new friends for the following droidcon conference days over a beer or mate.

Drinks will be sponsored by our friends from Novoda and by this Android conference that is currently in town... droidcon :)

name: Stammtisch August 2015
description:
We would also like to encourage you to give a talk, if you feel you have anything to share. Just reach out to us to get the details.

Talks

Understanding Android Handling of Touch Events
by Jens Mohrmann 

I'd like to show how Android handles Touch Events by means of extending an ExpandableListView with a swipe gesture. I'd like to explain which problems I encountered and how I solved them.

App Fails and Retrospectives
by Raymond Chenon

The talk is about "Best Practices" learnt from "Epic Fails" . 

Topics :

- Google Play update that went wrong. Especially when the app is going to be published as Editors' Choice . - Prediction : Android Marshmallow permissions

And more , come and see

name: Android Recreational Tinkering
description:
Android Recreational Tinkering is a weekly meetup for Android developers. It's a healthy mix of experienced developers and beginners. We come together to exchange knowledge, discuss new techniques and OS features, or simply work on our own apps and projects.

At the beginning we have a short round of introductions where everyone briefly talks about what they plan to work on during the meetup. This usually starts healthy discussions about different ways to solve a problem and formation of small groups to work on various projects.

New developers are always welcome! It doesn't matter if you just want to get to know the local Android community or if you have a specific problem you want to solve.

If you already know what you want to work on let us know in the comments!

name: Stammtisch September 2015
description:
Only one week after the joint event with GDG Berlin (GDG Meetup: High Performance Android & What's new in Cloud?) we come together again for the monthly meetup of Android developers. This time Wire is hosting us at their offices.

We're happy to announce that we have two speakers with us for this event:

• Sebastian Zabel will tell us how feasible it is to write Android apps in Go in his talk titled "Bind all the things: Go on Android".

• A Selim Salman will introduce us to "The World of Permissions in Android". A talk about history, present and the future of permissions on Android with a focus on how to use permissions effectively.

As always we invite the audience to share interesting Android development tidbits in the form of lightning talks. If you're interested in presenting, let us know in the comments or find one of the organizers during the event.

If you're not doing so already, you might also want to follow GDG Berlin Android on Google+.
how_to_find_us: 5th floor, use the staircase accessible from the entrance of Hof I or the elevator in Hof I

name: Stammtisch Oktober 2015
description:
After one month we will meet again for our monthly meetup of Android Developers. This time again at c-base.

We're happy to announce that we have currently one speaker with us for this event:

• Cesar Valiente will give his presentation "What you can/can't do with FLOSS (Free/Libre Open Source Software)"

Currently, most of all developers in the world use open source software, but most of them, actually, don't know how to use it, which open source license they have to use if they work on a privative software, if they can merge two different projects that use different licenses, if they can make money creating open source software, etc. So in this talk I will try to explain what you can and can not do with FLOSS.

As always we invite the audience to share interesting Android development tidbits in the form of lightning talks. If you're interested in presenting, let us know in the comments or find one of the organizers during the event.

If you're not doing so already, you might also want to follow GDG Berlin Android on Google+.

name: Android Recreational Tinkering presents: Android Development for Beginners
description:
The Android Recreational Tinkering (ART) lab invites you to a beginner's course in learning to program Android. We are roughly following the lessons at udacity 'android development for beginners'. 

This week we are focusing on Lesson 2a: Making an interactive app. Please try to do the lesson in advance, so we can discuss it in this meetup. 

But don't worry: If you are just starting from scratch, you are welcome to join, too. We focus on participants on all levels of experience, so first timers and experienced androids are equally welcome.

Please just make sure, that you bring a laptop with Android Studio installed. and sign up in this event to help us scale.

See you there!

name: DevFest Berlin 2015 - We are back!
description:
IMPORTANT: You need to have a ticket which is available at our event page: https://2015.devfest-berlin.de - Meetup RSVPs are not enough this time.

DevFest Berlin, https://2015.devfest-berlin.de/, is a once a year event organized by the Android, Cloud and Go GDGs from Berlin.

2.5 days of developer happiness with workshops, conference talks and a hackathon - organized and fueled by the community.

You can network with people from the coolest companies around as well as discover new things about your favorite topic. We are looking for speakers so check out https://2015.devfest-berlin.de/blog/call-for-participation/

for more details.

Would you rather attend this time rather than speaking? No worries, registration is open, just make sure you get your ticket in time from here

https://2015.devfest-berlin.de/#tickets

Looking forward to seeing you all there.

Have a nice day,

Your GDG organizers of Berlin

PS: Want to save a little more money? Use the offer code GDG-Berlin-Android_Friends (usable until it's not).

See you there!

name: Stammtisch November 2015
description:
November is an exciting month for Android developers. There was our very own DevFest Berlin 2015 with a track dedicated to Android. Then there's the Android Dev Summit (Nov 23-24) where sessions will be livestreamed. And the day after the summit we'll meet at c-base for the November Stammtisch.

Eugenio Marletti will give a talk on custom views. If you're new to Android development or haven't worked with custom views before this should be a nice introduction.

If you missed Marc Prengemann's talk "The Power of Custom Lint Checks" at Droidcon Berlin or Droidcon NYC you will be happy to learn that he is also giving the talk at our meetup.

Of course there will be plenty of time to have a drink and talk about everything Android.

The organizer team is looking forward to seeing you all at c-base.

name: Android Recreational Tinkering presents: Android Development for Beginners
description:
The Android Recreational Tinkering (ART) lab invites you to a beginner's course in learning to program Android. We are roughly following the lessons at udacity 'android development for beginners'. 

This week we are focusing on the second practice set.

If you are just starting from scratch, you are welcome to join. We focus on participants on all levels of experience, so first timers and experienced androids are equally welcome.

Please just make sure, that you bring a laptop with Android Studio installed and sign up in this event to help us scale.

See you there!

name: Android Recreational Tinkering
description:
Android Recreational Tinkering (ART) is a weekly meetup for Android developers. It's a healthy mix of experienced developers and beginners. We come together to exchange knowledge, discuss new techniques and OS features, or simply work on our own apps and projects.

At the beginning we have a short round of introductions where everyone briefly talks about what they plan to work on during the meetup. This usually starts healthy discussions about different ways to solve a problem and leads to formation of small groups to work on various projects.

New tinkerers are always welcome! It doesn't matter if you just want to get to know the local Android community or if you have a specific problem you want to solve.

If you already know what you want to work we encourage you to join our Android Developer Group Berlin Slacks #tinkering channel. There all attendees and organizers are encouraged to hang out.

name: Android Developer Meetup - March 2016
description:
Android N preview, bottom navigation, … we have lots to talk about. Be sure to come by c-base for the March edition of your favorite Android developer meetup in Berlin :)

We're happy to have Ronaldo Pace give a talk on how to Supercharge your RecyclerView.

Instead of a second talk we'll have a series of lightning talks presenting new features introduced in the Android N preview.

Multi locale support - Hasan Hosgel Quick settings tiles - Yasin Yildirim Doze mode changes - Danny Preussler Java 8 support - Eugenio Marletti Multi window support - Mario Bodemann Notification changes - cketti Of course there will be plenty of time to have a drink and talk about everything Android afterwards.

name: Android Developer Meetup - April 2016
description:
Our last meetup before the Google IO will have several interesting topics and will take place at the Sound Cloud Headquarter in the Factory Berlin.

We're happy to have Karolina Kafel and Guillaume Lung give an Introduction to LightCycle. LightCycle is a small library recently open sourced by our team at SoundCloud. It helps break the code out of Activities and Fragment classes and move it to small, self-contained components called Lifecyles.

Our Second presentation is by Caroline Smith and Lydia Selimalhigazi about "We are all on Team UX".

Description:

Designers and developers can make a powerful team, but we’ve noticed that sometimes miscommunication or differing perspectives can keep the product from reaching its full potential. This talk gives you practical tools to facilitate productive communication between developers and designers & increase the overall user experience of your products. Gain insight into how designers think and work, and learn some methods to have more effective working relationships between designers and developers.

Of course there will be plenty of time to have a drink and talk about everything Android afterwards.

name: Android Developer Meetup - May 2016
description:
This month's Android developer meetup is just one week after Google's developer conference Google I/O. And we have interesting things in store for you.

In case you missed it at droidcon Zagreb, now is your chance to listen to Florina Muntenescu's talk titled MVVM & RxJava - The Perfect Mix.

"Since the Model-View-Presenter pattern and RxJava have been adopted more and more in the Android community, the Model-View-ViewModel pattern emerged as a natural extension combining the benefits of these two concepts. Simple code snippets will be used to explain MVVM implementation and testing and showcase the advantages over MVP. Engineering war stories along with our lessons learned will be shared so you can avoid the mistakes we have made. I will also give you our answer for: is Rx a remedy for all ills and difficulties in every codebase or can the medicine have unforeseen adverse effects?"

Instead of a second presentation, we'd like to get a discussion going about the hottest new Android-related things announced at Google I/O. Audience participation is highly welcome :)

As always there will be plenty of time to socialize and enjoy cold beverages. See you there!

name: Android Developer Meetup
description:
Need another Android fix? droidcon Berlin is so far in the past you can hardly remember it? Don't worry, we've got you covered. Join your fellow Android developers to talk about… Android!
This month we have the following talks for you:

Natalie Pistunovich: Developing apps for developing countries

Developing apps for developing countries introduces new challenges: the smartphone is the main device, the internet data is limited due to infrastructure, and the demand is different. In this talk we'll see what are the initiatives to bring in more connectivity, what apps and connectivity are like in developing countries and what should you have in mind when developing such apps.

Volker Leck: Flag 'em - lessons from playing Minesweeper

The talk summarizes some experiences the author made while fiddling with a playground project, putting it into different contexts. We'll see how modularization is key when tackling new environments and how modern Android tooling (Gradle) can bring these different aspects under one umbrella.

Of course there will be plenty of time to socialize and enjoy cold beverages. See you there!

name: Android Developer Meetup - July 2016
description:
A lot has happend in the Android world and we want to bring you some new insights. 

Rene Groeschke, one of the Gradle developers, will talk about:

Gradle 3.0 for Android Developers

We’ll take a closer look on the approaching Gradle 3.0 release and what is in there for Android Developers.

Also Hendrik Kokocinski will give a presentation about:

Kotlin brings the fun to Android 

Kotlin is a JVM language that got a lot of attention since its release of v1.0 early this year. It is a lean modern language that makes you do more with less code. This talk will give you a quick introduction into the language suggesting why might want to use it for your future or even current projects.

Please note that the location for this meetup is ImmobilienScout24, not c-base. Oh, and there will be snacks and beverages.

name: Android Developer Meetup - August 2016
description:
Our two talks will be the following:

• Reactive Frustrations - Tomasz Polanski

"I would like to share the most common Rx challenges that a person with less than one year of experience usually has. If your issue is not one of them, I’ll introduce some approaches how to reason about you Rx streams and figure the solution by yourself."

• Virtual Reality in Android or Daydreaming about Cardboards - Mario Bodemann

"At this year's IO Google announced Daydream. I'll explain the current situation of the VR on Android by live coding two samples: One, using Unity for Android and iOS, another on how to write a simple photosphere app, written in pure Java, emphasizing the differences and similarities between both SDKs."

Like always, we expect some heavy socializing, and are similarly happy to see first time and regular attendees. We might even get a bit of sponsorship for this event from a local startup.

Feel free to join, or recommend us to your friends and coworkers. If you know an interesting talk topic, or someone who would like to hold a talk, please either reach out to us in person at the event, or through Twitter, e-mail, or G+.

name: Android Developer Meetup
description:
This time we would like to invite you to join your fellow Android developers at Onefootball office for talks, drinks and pizza :)

We will start with short presentation by Vane Georgiev about Working at Onefootball -

In this presentation, I will explain the steps we take, from ownership and kickoff to delivery, how we retrospect on every step and how we continuously look to improve our game.

Afterwards Ivan Morgillo gives his presentation Android Reactive Programming with Rx -

In a world where there is a smartphone in every pocket, designing and building applications that can run smoothly and deliver the User Experience that users deserve, is the only way to go. Rx will help you to beat Android platform limitations to create astonishing apps, with concepts that you can equally apply to every platform you work on. This talk will be a practical journey from basic Reactive Programming and Observer Pattern concepts to the main features of Rx, with code examples and a real-world app.

Last but not least Hasan Hosgel presents us Let's Map It! -

You will get an overview, what we can do these days with Google Maps on Android. A small history recap will be given and also a guide for the setup. We will learn, how we can change the styling of the map, using overlays, heat maps, street view and how we can cluster markers.

Like always, we expect some heavy socializing and are similarly happy to see first timers and regular attendees.

Feel free to join, or recommend us to your friends and coworkers. If you know an interesting talk topic, or someone who would like to hold a talk, please either reach out to us in person at the event, or through Twitter, e-mail, or G+.

name: Android Developer Meetup
description:
Our November meetup will have two talks:

The first talk will be by Ash Davies about migrating from Retrofit 1 to Retrofit 2 and it is called What the IOException!?.

The second talk will be given by  Fernando Cejas titled Hidden mysteries behind big mobile codebases (lessons learned).

You have a really cool and impactful project, but as soon as your codebase gets bigger, and more and more contributors come into play, things can become challenging in regards to aspects like: code consistency, technical debt, refactoring, application architecture and team organization. Let's jump onboard on this journey and walk through different techniques that can help us keep our code sane and healthy for better scalability.

Disclaimer: This talk is going to be focused from a mobile standpoint but most of the practices included can also be applied to any software project under development.

There will be plenty of time afterwards to have nice conversations while enjoying cool beverages.

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup - January 2017
description:
Join us for the first Berlindroid meetup of the year. We'll have the following two talks.

Falko Richter & Ronaldo Pace: Building an open source Android SDK - What we´ve leaned

The Sensorberg Android SDK is open source since 2015. We would like to share our learnings from building, maintaining the SDK. All topics will be backed by open source examples enabling everyone to pick up the progress we've made.

Said Tahsin Dane: Android Things: In & Out

Android Things is the new version of Android designed to run on small connected development devices like Raspberry PI, Intel Edison etc. It runs Android Nougat and lets you build connected devices for a wide variety of consumer, retail, and industrial applications.
In this talk, we will talk about what it is and how you do Android development with it. Then we will briefly compare with the other alternative solutions. Lastly, we will see how easy it is to connect Google’s Firebase infrastructure to have cloud connected devices.

Like always, there will be plenty of time for socializing. We're always happy to see both first timers and regular attendees.

Feel free to join, or recommend us to your friends and coworkers. If you know an interesting talk topic, or someone who would like to hold a talk, please either reach out to us in person at the event, or through Twitter, e-mail, or G+.

name: Android Developer Meetup
description:
Android O was announced, and we have some lightning talks and general knowledge about Android for you:

First, we'll have three 5 minutes lightning talks about Android O:
▪️Picture in picture: The full image,
▪️Autosizing TextView: Text at Scale and
▪️Notification Channels: Call me maybe.

Our first full length talk will be held by Christian, he will be talking about the infameous DiffUtil tool: How to use it. How not to. Get threading right and how to integrate it with Rx.

Following this talk, we'll give you the opportunity to talk quickly about anything Android: Do you need a job? Do you have a job? Do you need help with a job? What annoys you, what do you like?

For the second full length talk, Mario will be talking about Publishing Your Library: How to share your library with everyone. He'll do a presentation about the infamous Maven Central repository, how to contribute to our and show a nice platform called jitpack.io for ease of sharing branches in development.

Afterwards we have our great community to meet and talk to.

See you there!

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup - May 2017
description:
We're not tired of Android and will continue to meet to talk about developing for the best mobile OS on this planet!!!

This time, we are pleased to announce two super talks:

Jing Li will talk about "Docker for Android developers and why you should care":  
How does awesome Android benefit from dazzling Docker? With an introduction to the Docker way of continuous integration for Android, it would help you get a consistent Android development and build environment with no effort. Start to increase efficiency now, identify machine-dependant problems and get rid of them.

Eugenio Marletti will talk about "Kotlin: more than an island":
The last Google I/O was probably the most exciting ever, especially for one reason: Kotlin received official recognition as a first-class citizen on Android. 
The quantity of developers cheering for this shouldn't come as a surprise, as some of them have already been using the language for years, and for good reasons.
Join us to understand what Kotlin really is, and witness how its principles and advanced features make it so unique today, plus what will make it transcend into something even more powerful in the future.

After the talks, let's meet, chat and exchange ideas and of course, grab a few beers....

See you there!

name: Android Developer Meetup
description:
It's time again to meet fellow Android developers. We will have two presenters from our community. If you want to present a lighting talk, feel free to approach one of the organizers. Or use the possibility to raise your voice on our flea market. 

The first presenter will be Danny Preussler with The new ViewModel: a deep dive. 

Abstract:

Google announced at I/O Architecture Components - a set of libraries whose role is to improve the way we architect apps. One of the components is the ViewModel. Let’s look deeper than the usual “Hello, World” sample apps, to better understand how the ViewModel is working, how it’s implemented under the hood and if (and how) we can customize it.


Our second presenter will be Leandro Favarin with Don’t fear SQL: A better way to store and handle data with SQLBrite & SQLDelight.

Abstract:

In this talk he will present the reactive mindset behind SQLBrite and the code-generation capabilities of SQLDelight. When combined, these two libraries will help you architect and code safer and faster with queries autocompletion, code reuse, and much more.

We found a fresh new company, which want to host us. It is Evenly. Evenly is a mobile development agency focusing on high-quality apps for iOS and Android. They build apps for clients like ARTE, Berlin Philharmonics, funk, Grammofy, BVB and HSV.

Unfortunately, we had to limit the number of attendees. So please update your RSVP, if you can't join us anymore.

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup - July 2017
description:
To celebrate the currently awesome weather here in Berlin, we are meeting once more at c-base and will be talking about anything Android.

We'll be gathering at 19:30 and at 20:00 one of our two talks will start. In the time before, during and after the talks, we'll have enough time to talk to other Android developers, and see what they are about.

Our two talks will be the following:

No more □ (tofu)
by Miquel

Tofu is a slang for the empty boxes shown in place of undisplayable emojis. We all have seen it, and your users too. Google announced EmojiCompat at I/O as a solution for them, but does it solve all issues developers have with emojis? In our talk you'll learn from our experience dealing with emojis and if EmojiCompat is the best solution for you.

and

Fingerprint API - The how, the what and the why.

by Marvin

The Fingerprint API has been around since the Android Marshmallow release. Since then it has seen a lot of use, but also a lot of changes. In this talk we will cover how the Android Fingerprint API works, what to look out for when using it and the newest changes coming to the API.
Caution: This talk might contain traces of crypto.

Reach out to us if you'd like to give a talk.

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup - August 2017
description:
This month's meetup will take place at our favorite space station, c-base. Come listen to talks and mingle with fellow Android developers.

The first talk will be given by Ivan Morgillo and is titled Can you read my code?

We will never be able to write a piece of code and not looking at it ever again 'cos "It works!". When we collaborate with other people is critical to contribute with readable and maintainable code. In this presentation, I will share with you the Clue approach that helps us to achieve quality code and a healthy work environment.

Next, Robert Foss will tell us about Running Android on the Mainline Graphics Stack.

Finally, it is possible to run Android on top of mainline Graphics!
This talk will cover recent developments in the area which enabled the regular Open Source graphics stack to be used on Android devices.

In the beginning of September there's also droidcon Berlin. To welcome out-of-town Android developers we're having a little pre-droidcon party on Saturday. Please spread the word and sign up for the event here.

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup
description:
We are back with some knowledge sharing about Flutter and some insights about Kotlin:

1st talk: Kotlin Testing Robots by Ash

Following the announcement at this years Google IO we've seen a dramatic uptake in Kotlin and over the last few months we've learnt how we can use it to improve and produce clean architecture applications and supercharge our unit tests, but what about our UI tests?

In this session, I'll show you how you can utilise Kotlin with the Robot pattern to build concise, terse and easy to read UI tests


2nd talk: What's Awesome about Flutter by Wm

Flutter is a new architecture for building fast, beautiful apps that have received over a million downloads mobile  for Android and iOS from Google. This talk will discuss what is new and different about Flutter, and why developers are excited about it.


Come join the fun, learn some things and enjoy an open and social environment about the shinily green robot.

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup
description:
Let's talk about Android development. This month we'll have the following two presentations:

Miriam Busch, Muhammed Salih Güler, Álvaro Santisteban Diéguez: Improving development skills with Udacity's Android Nanodegrees – A team's review

Udacity and Google collaborated to create two online courses for Android developers: "Android Basics" and "Android Developer". We will share our experiences taking these classes from the points of view of a junior developer, an intermediate developer, a senior developer and their manager.

Stefan Medack: Data Classes and parsing JSON – A Story about converting Models to Kotlin 

Since the announcement of official Kotlin support at Google I/O we can be sure that Kotlin is here to stay and you can already feel the boost this language is getting. At Kitchen Stories we love this uprise and we are migrating our code base gradually to leverage the new features this language provides us.
In this session, I want to take you along the journey on how and why we migrated all our POJOs to POKOs. You will learn how Kotlins data classes, constructor default values and non-nullability can enable a more robust JSON parsing and how you can improve parsing with Moshi.

And of course there will be plenty of time to chat and enjoy a cold beverage or two.

You may also be interested to know that DevFest Berlin is right around the corner. It's a community-driven developer event that is organized by members of the various Google Developer Groups in Berlin. Get your tickets now before they're sold out: https://www.xing-events.com/THNHQBL.html

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup
description:
Let's meet and talk about Android.

Nelson Osacky - Automated Builds and Releases at Zenjob

Every company has their own special snowflake of an automated build and release process. In this talk I’ll walk through ours. Some topics I’ll cover include Travis CI, Travis UI testing, Firebase cloud test lab, Flank sharding on Firebase cloud test lab and automatic releases to GitHub and Play Store.


cketti - Profilers in Android Studio 3.0

The new Android Profiler in Android Studio 3.0 replaces the Android Monitor tools. These new profiling tools provide real-time data for your app's CPU, memory, and network activity.

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup
description:
It is two thousand eighteen! And we are back after the Holiday break. Like always we are loaded with awesome Android developers joining and with not less awesome talks:

----------------------------------

Say bye to Fragments with Conductor & Kotlin
by Miquel Beltran

Have you ever got a crash because you did something wrong with a Fragment? I did, many times! Fragments are not easy to use, and many experts even recommend to avoid them. But what is the alternative? We tried Conductor, we liked it and I am going to show you what can you do with it.

----------------------------------

2017 for Androids in Berlin
by Hasan Hosgel

Let us recap on the awesomeness that 2017 was.

----------------------------------

🏴‍☠️ ARrrrg! The Google AR Android Demo Application deciphered. 🏴‍☠️
by Mario Bodemann

This was my first reaction reading through the code of the sample provided by Google for it's new ARCore. After the first shock, I took a close look on how the app works, and what ARCore could do for my use case: Having my virtual collection of toy figures always with me ❤️. 🤖🤴

----------------------------------

In between the talks we have plenty of awesome time to talk to other Android developers, give feedback on talks and enjoy a drink or two from the bar. Additionally we will have the `flea market` section, where you can present your quick ideas/joboffers/questions to our audience. Think of it as you personal open microphone night, without too much singing.

Awesome for you to join and read this far. See you awesomely at the event...

Drinks will be sponsored by Karlmax Berlin.

name: Android Recreational Tinkering
description:
Android Recreational Tinkering (ART) is a weekly meetup for Android developers. It's a healthy mix of experienced developers and beginners. We come together to exchange knowledge, discuss new techniques and OS features, or simply work on our own apps and projects.

Please bring your Laptop with you.

New tinkerers are always welcome! It doesn't matter if you just want to get to know the local Android community or if you have a specific problem you want to solve.

If you already know what you want to work we encourage you to join our Android Developer Group Berlin Slacks #tinkering channel. There all attendees and organizers are encouraged to hang out.

name: Android Co-Learning
description:
Android Co-Learning is a weekly meetup for Android developers. It’s a healthy mix of experienced developers and beginners. We come together to exchange knowledge, help beginners, discuss new techniques and OS features. Please bring your Laptop with you.

Who this meetup is for:
- beginners: come by and ask us any question you have. We will help you regardless it is installing AndroidStudio or making VR app;
- experienced: come by and share your knowledge and help our new Android fellows or ask questions to other experienced attendees, or just to work on your own projects.

There is no strict rule. Just come by and let’s share a good time!

We encourage you to join our Slack group “Android Developer Group Berlin”. Visit https://adg-berlin.herokuapp.com and there you can find #co-learning channel. There all attendees and organizers are encouraged to hang out.

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup - February 2018
description:
This time we're trying something new and will have shorter talks (~20 min). But instead of two we'll have four talks.

1. JitPack - Packaging Git (Christian)
JitPack builds your GitHub repositories without any interference from you. This time you’ll hear about the undocumented and well hidden features which make JitPack more seamless and practical.

2. Command line magic for the Android developer (Christopher Orr)
Something about various relatively unknown features and command line tools that are useful for Android development.

3. Testing time (Tomek Polanski)
"It is said that we are not able to stop or change the time - fortunately we developers, don't tend to listen to others! I will share how to use the virtual time to improve the quality of Unit and UI tests."

4. JUnit 5 on Android: Through the eyes of Kotlin (Danny Preussler)
Danny is talking about his favorite topic, testing. This time he'll have a look at Junit 5.

Like always you're invited to hang out with people from your favorite Android community before and after the talks. We're looking forward to seeing you all 👀

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup - March 2018
description:
We will have the following talks:

Said Tahsin Dane, Tobias Heine - Multiplatform Kotlin

In this talk we will deep dive into JetBrains multiplatform projects feature, why you should consider using it and how you can do so to level up your product development.

Dmytro Kuiko - Let's take a look at our brother.

We will try to expose Uncle Bob's approach to Viper by providing Router to it. With it help we will navigate easily through different situations like: wizards, authentification, validation cases and most importantly handle fragments which could be not so bad :)

Enjoy

name: Berlindroid - Android Developer Meetup
description:
The best Android developer meetup in town 😉

A first talk will be presented by Doug Sillars:
"It's Time to Stop Stalling: Mobile App and Video Performance"

In this talk, we'll look at tools to identify mobile performance issues, some common pitfalls, and how they are resolved. We'll give a special focus to mobile video streaming- a fast-growing yet challenging facet in mobile apps.

The second talk will be presented by Mohsen Mirhoseini:

"Using Protobuf in Android apps plus extra Kotlin flavor"

Protocol Buffers is a method of serializing structured data developed by Google for internal usage which also provided a code generator for multiple languages. In this talk I am going to talk about serializing structured data as shrink as possible using Google Protobuf inside your Android app and a fast comparison between this protocol and JSON.

This month we will make it in a SonyCenter: Careem Networks/WeWork
how_to_find_us: Walk through glass door and Careem personal will show you the way. Please be there on time (at least 19:30)
